comments.commentBody: If these elections are only contested in a couple "swing" states, does the winner really have a mandate for anything?  The best reason to dump the Electoral College is that it would force the candidates to present their cases to people all over the country, and let us make decisions as a country.  We are one country, after all.

As Karen Garcia very ably points out in the comment above, few Democratic politicians these days live up to the New Deal heritage of their party. This election therefore cannot be framed as a referendum on the New Deal; it will at best be a "choice" between Republicans who would openly and aggressively destroy New Deal programs, versus Democrats who have for three decades ceded piecemeal the essence of these programs and their principles.

Under the reign of the present two major parties, nothing will improve for the majority of Americans until the Democrats find their spines and hormone-producing ellipsoids. Should that not occur within a reasonable time, either a new political party that not only talks the talk but also walks the walk of social and economic justice will arise, or the pitchfork brigades may mobilize faster than either the politicians or the television talking heads could ever believe possible.

Raising tax rates, especially on high-income earners (including the capital gains rate), is also one of the things that will need to be done to blalance the budget. Framing the issue as a false choice between slashing entitlements and letting the deficits and debt grow is one of the things that the Republican party has largely gotten away with. Moreover, there really isn't that much money to realistically go after with entitlements (other than Social Security, Medicare, and Obamacare, which are effectively off the table, and rightly so). The only area where significant spending cuts can realistically be made is the defense department, and it's an area that Republicans, for the most part, won't even touch.

Although people in some segments of society may be living longer that does not necessarily mean they can manage their work lives effectively past the (already extended) age for full social security benefits. This is obvious for people who do physical labor whose bodies may be ravaged by a lifetime of hard work (a huge swath of blue collar workers and tradespeople) but also relevant for white collar workers and business people.

Means testing for Social Security makes better sense but no one who has paid in should be denied benefits altogether.

" That some segments of the population are regressing in terms of longevity, namely those with very low economic situations and poor educations, but this is attributable to poor diet, poor lifestyle choices, and poor access to healthcare."

Only someone who hasn't been poor for an extended period of time could write that. Poor people like to feel full after they've eaten, too!

Buy the 5 lb. sack of potatoes instead of the Yukon Gold, and 1/3 of each potato is lost to black spots inside. The economy pack of chicken thighs is basically chemical soup, and tastes like it. Consumer Reports just had an article about high arsenic levels in rice. The cheaper food is per calorie, the more calories are empty of nutrition.

Smokers and non-smokers in the plastics molding industry both die of emphysema. Poorer neighborhoods are closer to landfills, incinerators, refineries, and other polluting industries.

High stress is a killer. The poor have little control over their own circumstances, and we know what that does to lab monkeys.

If even liberals and progressives are going to buy into the "poor choices" trope, could it be that many poor subconsciously buy into the idea that "...they had better [die], and decrease the surplus population."?

@TR: It isn't just poor diet and lack of health care that makes people ready to retire before their late sixties. How many 67 year old roofers have you seen? Heavy labor takes its toll and always has. The percentage of the workforce in heavy labor is less than it used to be, but it's still significant. True, those no longer able to work can file for disability, but that's a protracted process. Even disregarding the effect on the worker, disability claims are much more expensive for the government. If the retirement age goes up, disability claims will increase. I also wonder when someone rattles off means testing as a panacea whether any thought has been given to the cost and intrusiveness of means testing. Do you want the Social Security Administration to bulk up on employees so as to be able to delve into beneficiaries' finances each year?

In a sense social security benefits are already means tested. They become taxable income if total income exceeds a threshold. But that's been true for at least twenty years so obviously isn't what the means test advocates want. However if you really must means test benefits, making them taxable as income would seem to be the most cost effective way to do it. You could raise the tax rate or lower the threshold if you want to take benefits away from people with other means. But of course we must never talk about tax increases. Much better to just impose more red tape to deny people their benefits.

Life expectancy is increasing - substantially so - for the population as a whole.  It's increased approximately 13 years since Social Security was instituted as part of the New Deal.  So increasing the age of eligibility is something that must be considered.  That some segments of the population are regressing in terms of longevity, namely those with very low economic situations and poor educations, but this is attributable to poor diet, poor lifestyle choices, and poor access to healthcare.  This illustrates the  critical importance of establishing the type of quality health care that the ACA means to provide to this population.  For as Prof Krugman is well aware, the costs of healthcare for treating chronically ill, poorly treated persons who present with the complications of their diseases - for example a stroke, heart attack, or kidney failure resulting from untreated hypertension - are astronomically higher than they would be if the disease were properly diagnosed, treated, and monitored earlier in that person's life.  Raising the eligibility age is just good common sense.  So is means testing.  And one thing should be instituted:  if  someone who is eligible for Medicare still has employer-provided health care, then they should required to take it.  Some kind of tax credit might be applied to offset the loss of this benefit, but Medicare - and Social Security for that matter - should be benefits provided to those who truly need them.

I started by agreeing with you, but your post goes downhill towards the end. Let me try to answer the questions which you seem to think are unanswerable.

"why exactly should dividends ...have preferred tax treatment over wage and salaries?"
Because dividends come out of a company's profits AFTER it has paid tax on those profits. Taxing profits, and then taxing them again when they are distributed to the company's owners, is double taxation.

"why exactly should ... capital gains income ... have preferred tax treatment over wage and salaries?"
In times like this, of low inflation, perhaps they shouldn't. But in times of high inflation, which we had in the past and will surely have again, taxing "gains" is simple confiscation. Suppose you bought an investment in 1970 for $1,000 and sold it in 1980 for $10,000. You'd be taxed on $9,000 of "gain". But in fact, you made a loss, not a gain, because it would have cost you more than $10,000 in 1980 to buy the same goods that would have cost $1,000 in 1970.
The fair thing to do would be to tax the real gain (after allowing for inflation). But that's too complicated for our politicians. Giving special treatment to cap gains is a workaround. It's not great, but it's less unfair than taxing them as income.

Ron, I agree with you regarding most of this but would be a bit careful on moving willy nilly to include all cap gains and dividends as normal income for two reasons.

1. Most economists will say that, absent a desire to create an incentive, all income streams should have equivalent taxation. You are not actually doing this for dividends because they are post corporate tax. So, e.g., if my marginal tax rate is, say, 39% as the highest may soon be, and my company pays the corporate tax rate of 35%, the effective dividend tax is 60%. That creates a big incentive for companies to hold onto money they earn, even if the quality of reinvestment is poor, rather than giving it back to the shareholders. (Think lots of failed M&A) Bad for business, bad for the country. Better to make the two streams equivalent, say by taking down the corporate tax rate to 25% (closer to international norm, so less hiding money abroad) but getting rid of the many loopholes that cause many businesses to pay a far lower rate today and then set the dividend rate to something that makes the total taxation equivalent to the income rate - abt 20% in the case of the 39% top income tax rate. (that's up from 15% today)

2. Then there is the question of whether we actually want to encourage investment by preferentially taxing cap gains and dividends? I think so, but cap it so that the preferential benefit goes to those who really need those extra savings - the middle class.

VR and Kay -

I am paid for my carpentry work with after-tax money.
I buy my groceries with after-tax money.
I am a person.
A corporation is a person.

Tell me again why the person receiving dividend income should get credit for taxes paid by the person paying the dividend?

Problem solved. Budget deficits?  Return to the Clinton rates which produced surpluses, and eliminate outrages like the "carried interest" tax preference that allows billionaire hedge fund managers to pay taxes at rates half that of the middle class, and oil companies to pay nothing.  And why exactly should dividends, or capital gains income-which require no work- have preferred tax treatment over wage and salaries? How about going back to policies that reward work, not Wall Street casino speculators?

The H1B visa program has destroyed the American middle class.

It's really a simple case of supply and demand. Consider an analogy. Consider, for example, what would happen if H1B were applied to plumbers instead of engineers.

Pick any city, let's say, Denver, Colorado. Now, bring in 100 busloads of freshly graduated plumbers (4,000 new plumbers), who want to enter into the plumbing business in Denver, and make a living.

The result? Wage rates for plumbers will become depressed. The existing 960 plumbers in Denver, once busy every day, and making a good living, will now have much less work, or no work at all.

Who can compete with improverished hordes of plumbers from India who will work for any price? India has 1.17 BILLION people, and many of them are coming here, flooding our labor markets.

The H1B visa law was created, written and lobbied for by large American corporations as a means for decreasing their engineering labor costs. Indeed their corporate profits have zoomed up, up, up -- while the wage rates paid to their American engineers have gone down, down, down.

This is what the H1B visa has done to the American engineering profession. H1B has already brought in over one million foreign engineers to America, thus driving down wages, closing American engineering schools, and discouraging American kids from majoring in engineering.

I addition, obesity is best dealt with by universal health care and a payment system to doctors that rewards prevention rather than testing for potential money earning procedures or more tests.

Surveys show that most Republican voters believe that WMDs were found in Iraq and that President Obama is a Muslim (not, of course, that there'd be anything wrong with it if he was). Right now, conservative media outlets are decrying the polls showing that Obama is ahead as "biased," After President Obama wins reelection, I suspect that another excuse for why the Republicans were robbed of victory will be found (perhaps the "liberal media bias"). Bottom line: It might not actually matter if the Republicans take a drubbing in the elections. I suspect that they're not going to reevaluate their policies; they're only going to make excuses, come back in the future with more voter suppression tactics, and possibly recraft their message so that, in their view, it will sell better.

Middle ground is only in the middle if both sides are the same distance from the center. I think President Obama is ahead because most people in this country are more interested in their family's future than in Ayn Rand.

Perhaps you observe a Canadian phenomenon. Certainly not true in the US. Most CS undergrad curricula follow CS ABET accreditation guidelines, whether they actually seek that optional imprint or not. Proficiency in more than one programming language and operating system, and familiarity with others, is the norm. Language survey classes introduce paradigms they will see in their professions. Capstone courses typically require group software development projects that lead to larger software outputs and familiarity with working with others. When I was active in academia, our goal was a graduate who could say to a recruiter: "I know a lot of stuff that is useful to your company now. I know how to learn any new language or system and be proficient in six weeks. Shall we begin?"

Of course more theoretical coursework, like the algorithmic complexity subject you denigrate, is required to understand the basic choices between efficient and grossly inefficient methods at large scale. Computability topics have value--too many undergrads think that anything can be sensibly attacked with deterministic computer software, and we cannot let a graduate loose upon the world with that misconception.

New small businesses are overwhelmingly started by people whose net worth is less than $250,000 and whose income from the businesses they start is also much less than that, for the first few years at least.

I feel like I'm reading Pravda. Paul Krugman thinks that there is no economic problem vis a vis deficits. This is shocking to me. Anyone with reading skills know that we have a huge financial problem in this country. At some point soon, the money taps will be shut off and no one will lend to America. Then what? Austerity measures. Then what? Riots in the streets of America.

What none of you realize is that the "wealthy" pay the lion's share of taxes in America. If you raise tax rates on the job creators, you will have less economic activity because taxes are a disincentive to investors. Investors will invest elsewhere where taxes are lower. We should have the lowest business and capital gains tax rates in the world to show all investors that we are open for business.

I fail to understand why progressives can not understand this. You are all fighting over how to share the pie. We should, instead, be figuring out how to grow the pie.
